title.narrative: Support for Caritas South Sudan Emergency Appeal EA 01-2018

description.narrative:
Political instability and sustained violence have been pervasive in South Sudan for its six years of independence. The resumption of widespread fighting leaves civilians at risk of further mass crimes, particularly during the dry season when troops are more mobile. According to the UN Office for Humanitarian Coordination (UN OCHA), political conflict, compounded by economic woes and drought, has caused massive displacement, violence and dire food shortages. 4.8 million People are in need of aid, and by March 2018, 5.1 million people are estimated to continue facing hunger.
South Sudan in 2017 experienced famine which the UN Humanitarian Coordinator for South Sudan called it a "man-made" situation. According to the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), more than 194,000 people have fled to Uganda since the start of 2017. At least 50,000 people were killed and more than 1.5 million people have fled South Sudan since December 2013. An additional 2.1 million people remain internally displaced.
The fiscal deficit, inflation and parallel market premium have all gone up, this macroeconomic collapse has severely affected the livelihood of many South Sudanese, Urban poverty jumped from 49% in 2015 to 70% in 2016 with wages losing their purchasing power, white colour workers and other employees have been driven to poverty in after not paid for months. Deficits associated with the war and with security spending have been financed by printing money.
The monetization of the fiscal deficit by the Bank of South Sudan explains the country’s high inflation. The rate of inflation peaked at 550% in September 2016. The pace of printing of money has slowed in recent months, so inflation decelerated to 102% during September 2016–September 2017 (Consumer Price index for South Sudan published by the National Bureau of Statistics in November 2017).
Notwithstanding the recent down tend, galloping inflation continues to put many households in both urban and rural areas in a stressful situation because they are unable to afford even the minimum food basket.
